:( damn. I am a nurse, although I work in surgery now and not on the floor. Definitely have a word with the unit nurse or nurse manager in charge, however with that said the nursing system is hierarchical and if upper management is shit, don't expect lower management to be any good. I'm so sorry you are going through this - I've seen my fair share of apathetic nurses. It's a stressful job where you often have to let go of your own humanity just to get by each day what with seeing death and illness all day. Not to mention we're overworked and underpaid. Still though, not an excuse.
I can understand why some nurses are upset about visitors - it messses up their schedule especially if there is more than one visit a day. Also, be careful about thinking the nurses and doctors are being dismissive. Chances are they have run tests and are investigating issues and expected that there would be fever, I mean, infections usually always lead to fever. Sometimes a lot of the things we do don't make sense to the lay person, but if it's anything like the hospital my friend did her placement at, if they're underfunded and understaffed they will under supply and under medicate due to cost and only act when they feel they absolutely must. Which sucks, but it's happening and governments need to step in and fix this issue.
I am so sorry about you going through a rough time. Some hospitals have a counselling service that you can contact. Maybe look into that for some in house guidance and support. Best of luck to both you and your partner.

It's really unnecessary. That's what the SSRIs are meant to do - keep you calm. Are you seeing a Psych or a doctor? Doctors are not really trained thoroughly in handling psychiatric drugs. Not to mention Klonopin is a benzo, it's addictive and can lead to sexual dysfunction. I find it unusual that it has been prescribed. Usually you only get benzos if the SSRIs are not enough, but you never had them on their own. I'd recommend seeing someone else. I took benzos for a time, but as mentioned I had quite severe PTSD as well. It's left as a last line of defence

First off, not being able to cum is not a good reason to quit taking anti-depressants for panic disorder. 6 weeks is when the SSRIs start doing their job, especially for a slow activating drug like Fluoxetine.
Now, I have panic disorder as well. It's great isn't it. :) I was first put on a drug called escitalopram or Lexapro. It has a diminished effect on sex drive (ie, I was pretty horny all the time), but it made me feel sick (am Asian, apparently Asians cannot metabolise the drug well). So I was put on Fluoxetine which made me so apathetic towards sex and then Zoloft which made it so difficult for me to stay hard. After that I was finally put on a high dose of a drug called citalopram (Celexa) which had been a god send for my panic attacks, depression and my sex life.
The great and shit thing about SSRIs is that there are so many drugs out there. You need to do a little playing around to find a good one. It was a little hard for me because I had comorbid depression and PTSD and was in more than just anti-depressants. But citalopram has been the go to drug for psychiatrists in treating panic disorder. You find some luck there, but like I said. It will depend on how your body metabolises them. I recommend getting a genetic pharmacology test, no idea what they are called, but basically they screen for all medicines for all illnesses to find which will best suit you according to your genetics. It becomes quite useful in the future.
Also, why are you taking Klonopin? If you are still restless and have insomnia despite the SSRI you are on, you need to switch. Citalopram really got me to go to sleep when I should, but Fluoxetine and escitalopram did not. You'll have to have a chat with your psychiatrist over this.

Side effects depend on the course of treatment you take, but weight loss? No, not to the extent he says. It is possible that the HIV has made him lose weight, but he would either have to not be taking the drugs or have a really high viral load.
Facial tics, no, they are a very abnormal symptom. Acting weird - well that could be due to increased fatigue, nausea, gastrointestinal problems and headaches. But the changes are not dramatic. It's not like chemotherapy. To me, as a nurse, I'd be concerned he is on some sort of drug as well.

Well this brings me way back to PSYC1001. This was commonly a behaviouralist approach to human behaviour and psychology - think B.F Skinner and Steven Pinker who consider humans to be born as (close to) blank slates by which experience determines our behaviours and attitudes.
The modern psychology approach is more biopsychology which is sometimes referred to as cognitive psychology which takes concepts of behavioural psychology, but says that there are inherent innate neurological patterns, preferences and responses as well as genetics which determine outcomes. So depending on which school of thought you like more it either means you are what you experience, or you are what your genetics determine the product of that experience to be.

I feel like if you are still living home and not taking advantage of that by going to college or work, you're in for a rough future. I understand the job market is abysmal. When I was at university I could not land any jobs in retail or the likes for over 3 years! Thankfully I had professional ballet training so I could teach that. I wouldn't be surprised that he can't find stable work - the market is what it is.
However, unless he can't afford to go to college, he doesn't have an excuse not to go. Personally I could sympathise with someone in his position, but if you're not working full-time or studying full-time, then you are just wasting crucial future building time. I had however been in a similar situation, but my husband had plates put into his back after an accident when he was deployed and was in a wheelchair for over 2 years. He could not work or study for 6 months so I picked up the slack. However, I feel that's a different situation. It's hard though, because being the only breadwinner puts a lot of pressure on you to provide for two people on a one person wage

You will be surprised at what will be useless in other countries. Even things like computer science, medicine and health science courses can become redundant. Unless the language course you are studying is accredited by the country's national assessment standard, then it will be useless and you may have to restart your study following their national curriculum. In the case of German, a university course must follow the Goethe-Institut structure and produce the same outcomes, otherwise it's relearning and exams to get a visa.

You sound great. :) There are plenty of fat/chubby guys who find love, you have just got to own it and be confident. Your confidence will improve when you find flattering clothes, work out and eat healthier. While I suffered from anorexia, my goal was to put on weight. What really kicked my body dysmorphia was to start working out - I could breathe better, I was getting a more attractive body (sort of) and I just felt better inside. I also cooked. Cook, cook, cook. And I love cooking now. I scheduled in two days of vegetarian/vegan food only and it really got me used to eating healthier and better (before that I was just taking multivitamins, dry biscuits and sugary food).
I'm not saying this to make you lose weight, but rather a good diet and exercise do help with confidence and feeling better.
If you are dealing with feelings of depression, I recommend seeing a doctor about getting your hands on some SSRIs/SNRIs. It's easy for people to say "hey get confident and socialise more!" but sometimes there is a barrier or illness which gets in the way, when you receive the proper help, then you can start doing those things and will see better results with how people treat you. :)
